misconceptions.name: Implemented distance calculator instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points rather than reading a single numeric grade and printing the corresponding letter grade as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve this assignment by writing a program that reads two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and prints the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read one numeric grade between 0 and 100 from the user and then use conditional statements to map that numeric grade to a letter grade (A, B, C, D, F) according to the specified ranges, and print the letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, and y2 instead of a single grade.
Program computes a distance using the distance formula rather than evaluating grade ranges.
Program output is 'The distance of the two points is ...' instead of 'Letter grade: X'.
No conditional logic exists for grade ranges 90-100, 80-89, etc.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different textbook or lab problems, leading to implementing a completely different specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and rewrite the program so it asks for a single numeric grade (0-100), then use if/else-if/else statements to check which range the grade falls into and print the correct letter grade.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric ranges to categorical outputs
Basic program design based on requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is focused on distance between points with no trace of grade-related input, conditionals, or output, which directly contradicts the assignment description.

evidence.note: The code reads coordinates for two points and computes their distance; it never reads a numeric grade or outputs a letter grade, so it does not address any of the rubric criteria for the grade calculator.

misconceptions.name: Task Mismatch / Incorrect Program Submitted
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a completely different program ('Distance Between Points' calculator) instead of the required 'Grade Calculator' (Q3). No part of the specified grading logic or input requirement was met.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student likely submitted the wrong file or misinterpreted the assignment instructions, believing the provided code addressed the required problem (Q3).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read a single numeric grade and use conditional statements (if/else if/else) to determine and print the corresponding letter grade based on the given scale.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a grade
Missing all required conditional logic for grading
misconceptions.root_cause: Submission error or fundamental confusion regarding the assigned task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure the submitted code matches the problem description for Q3 (Grade Calculator). The code must input a single grade, not four coordinates.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire code is dedicated to the Distance formula, a mathematically and functionally distinct problem from grading, confirming a critical task mismatch.

evidence.note: The code implements input and calculation for the distance formula, not grade calculation.

misconceptions.name: Wrong problem solved - distance calculation instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted code that calculates the distance between two points rather than implementing the grade calculator program specified in the assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a distance calculation problem, not a grade calculator problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on specified ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a grade
Program calculates Euclidean distance instead of determining letter grade
No conditional logic for grade ranges (A/B/C/D/F)
Output is completely unrelated to the rubric requirements
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either worked on the wrong assignment file, copied code from a different problem, or misread the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment specification carefully. Start over by: (1) reading a single integer grade with Scanner, (2) using if-else statements to check the ranges (90-100, 80-89, 70-79, 60-69, <60), (3) printing the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code is entirely unrelated to the grade calculator problem. It solves a completely different problem (distance between two points), making it impossible to meet any of the rubric criteria for Q3.

evidence.note: The entire program solves a distance calculation problem, not the grade calculator specified in Q3. Class name, input prompts, and output are all for a different problem.

misconceptions.name: Implemented distance calculator instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points rather than a program that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade A–F as specified.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task is to read two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and compute the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read one numeric grade between 0 and 100, then use conditional statements to determine which letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) corresponds to that number and print the letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, and y2 instead of a single numeric grade.
No conditionals or Boolean ranges to map numeric grades to letter grades.
Program prints a numeric distance value instead of a letter grade such as A, B, C, D, or F.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misreading or confusing this problem with a different assignment about computing the distance between two points.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and rewrite main so it reads one integer or double grade from 0 to 100, uses if/else-if conditions to check the grade ranges (90–100, 80–89, etc.), and prints the appropriate letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All input prompts, variables, and the final output are about point coordinates and distance; there is no mention of grades or letter output anywhere in the code.

evidence.note: The entire program is structured around reading two coordinate points and computing their distance; it never reads a single grade or outputs a letter grade as required.

misconceptions.name: Solved wrong problem (Distance Formula instead of Grade Calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program (DistanceBetweenPoints) that calculates the distance between two points, which is a completely different task than the required Grade Calculator problem. No attempt was made to read a single numeric grade (0-100) or calculate a letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student likely submitted template code or a solution to a previous problem, believing it was the required solution for Q3, or fundamentally misunderstood the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read a single numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional statements (if/else if/else) to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Code calculates distance formula using four inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2)
No logic exists for grade calculation or conditional branching based on grade criteria (90, 80, 70, 60)
misconceptions.root_cause: Major confusion regarding which problem to solve or accidental submission of incorrect source code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment instructions for Q3 (Grade Calculator) and implement the logic specifically for that problem using a Scanner to read a single integer/double for the grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is entirely functional Java code solving the distance calculation problem, unequivocally failing to address any part of the Grade Calculator problem defined in the prompt and rubric.

evidence.note: Class name reflects solving the wrong problem.
Reads four coordinates instead of a single grade.
Implements distance calculation, not grade logic (conditionals).
